Benjamin Tse

Engineer Maker Innovator

More about me

Hi, I am Benjamin. Lightshade is my nickname.

I aim to develop technologies with a focus on innovation and the development of robotic solutions. I believe that technological advancement will improve our standards of living while reducing the monotonous and dangerous work people do.

My goal is to be an innovator who can combine design and engineering with business and customer needs to provide solutions that can create a significant impact on peopleâ€™s lives.

Outside of work, I spend my time making and tinkering on my little projects such as the kinetic drizzle and canard Y4 RC aircraft. I also enjoy learning new skills online which could be useful to me in the future.

I've worked at...

NUS | Research Engineer

I work on some cool sensors and HOPES, a tonometry device that isn't uncomfortable to use.

Mar 2021 - Feb 2023

Did the mechanical design of Vline drone tethers and the Lumicopter.

Flytrex | Field Engineer

Jan 2019 - July 2019

Had the opportunity to intern at one of the world's leading drone delivery startups and it was truly an eye-opening experience.

CFB Bots | Associate

Jan 2019 - July 2019

During this internship, I did Robotic Process Automation (RPA) scripts to automate client's repetitive work.

Kinetic Drizzle

This is a personal project that is still a work in progress. The idea is to build a table top sized version of the Kinetic Rain display at Changi Airport. Part of this project is in challenging myself to do and learn electronics at a deeper level through a practical approach while still utilizing simple and cheap components.

The project utilizes simple and cheap components, making it cheap and easily reproducible.

Canard Rotor Wing

This was the my final year project in NUS. In this project, I built and attempt to validate the working efficiency of an electric canard rotor wing aircraft.

The research of this type of aircraft was not new and has been done by Boeing in the Dragonfly project. However, an electric version of this aircraft was not attempted before and I wanted to know if it was feasible to think of this aircraft as a replacement to conventional drones. This project proved to be a significant challenge to my skills, but it gave me many opportunities to hone my engineering skills for my future endeavours.

Canard Y4 VTOL

The goal of this project was to attempt the craziest Radio-Controlled (RC) aircraft that I could think of. The aircraft features a canard front wing with a main wing that has both forward and backward sweep and taper. Calculations for lift and stability were done using OpenVSP and other airfoil tools.

It uses 4 motors in a Y4 configuration for VTOL. The rear motors on the main wing are coupled together and rotate backwards for forward flight using a single servo and a Geneva mechanism. The motors and transition mechanism were programmed using Inav with a F4 flight controller.

Eventually, I managed to test its vertical flight mode only before I wanted to move on to other projects; you can check it out in the link below =). I had great fun working this project and I learned a lot. I do hope that one day I can revisit this project in the future to make it work.

  • Video link: Click here

Triturn - Innoventure

One of the hackathons that I participated in, where my team and I achieved finalist places after a year of work. We created a means to reduce the physical strain on nurses when they had to turn over patients to prevent the onset of pressure ulcers. It involves a simple piece of shaped fabric and mechanical equipment that is already present in hospitals.

Unfortunately, we did not have the funding or commitment to bring this project further. Perhaps if we did, we would have made a successful product, seeing as how Handicare USA has took the idea and is selling a very similar product with a similar name, which was launched soon after our hackathon ended. =)
